data.title: Universal lines up Martin Luther King Jr. biopic. Chris Rock to direct, Spielberg EP. Entertainment
data.text:
DinkyDev

The Movie Critic

Feb 5, 2021

6,494

Oct 5, 2023

#1

Universal Pictures is gearing up to tell a definitive cinematic biopic about the life of Martin Luther King Jr. The studio has optioned the rights to adapt Jonathan Eig's critically acclaimed biography King: A Life. Chris Rock is in final talks to direct and produce, and Steven Spielberg will be executive producer.

The film will be produced by Amblin Partners, with Kristie Macosko Krieger serving as producer along with Rock. King: A Life has been a big bestseller, and is nominated for the National Book Award. It has been hailed as a definitive biography of the civil rights icon Dr. King, for its use of previously untapped sources that include newly declassified FBI information. The book sketches out the courageous man who demanded peaceful protests in the segregationist south, all the while grappling with his own frailties and a federal government that haunted his every step instead of treating him like the hero history shows him to be.

This is a great opportunity for the talented Rock to put being the recipient of "the Oscar slap" squarely in the rearview mirror. Rock co-stars in the George C. Wolfe-directed Rustin, which stars Colman Domingo as Bayard Rustin, the man who organized the 1963 march on Washington, where Dr. King made his iconic "I have a dream" speech that galvanized the battle to desegregate the south. In Rustin, Rock plays the pivotal role of Roy Wilkins, the NAACP leader who reluctantly embraced Rustin's efforts and made the march possible. That film's produced by Higher Ground for Netflix.

I know I'm going very much against the grain on this one, but I honestly feel that Spielberg was the wrong guy for The Color Purple back then, too. I don't doubt his intentions were good and pure, the final product being very clear on that, but that film is way too glossy and pristine for the story that he's trying to tell and he had a particularly bad instinct to try and have a "look on the bright side" kind of approach to contrasting the drama that gets into the ugly side of domestic life for Blacks in that time that winds up undermining a lot of that drama. And that's not even getting into how much the film whitewashes the fuck out of the queerness at the heart of the relationship between Celie and Shug, which even he has admitted to being ill-equipped to telling in the years since. It is undeniably a well-made film, Spielberg had amazing instincts for casting both Whoopi Goldberg and Oprah Winfrey before anyone knew who they were, and it is absolutely a milestone for Black representation on film since it was a major drama that got all the resources it needed, but it's also a flawed adaptation on an inherent level simply because of who made it.
